questionList.questionText: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the office for a routine newborn examination.  She was born by vaginal delivery at 39 weeks gestation to a 26-year-old primigravida.  The pregnancy and delivery were otherwise uncomplicated, and prenatal ultrasonography revealed normal fetal anatomy.  The patient is fed formula every 3-4 hours and sleeps 5-6 hours overnight.  She lives at home with her parents and grandparents.  Physical examination shows an alert infant who is moving all extremities equally.  There are 4 skin creases along the inner left thigh and 1 on the right.  When the patient is supine with the knees flexed, the left knee appears to be inferior to the right knee.  Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers are negative.  The remainder of the examination is normal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Developmental dysplasia of the hip

Pathophysiology

  • Abnormal development of acetabulum & femoral head → hip instability

Risk factors

  • Mechanical: breech positioning, excessively tight swaddling
  • Genetic: female sex, family history

Clinical
features

  • Infants
    • Hip instability (eg, positive Barlow &/or Ortolani maneuver)
    • Leg asymmetry (eg, positive Galeazzi sign, asymmetric gluteal/thigh folds)
  • Older children
    • Limited hip abduction
    • Leg-length discrepancy
    • Trendelenburg gait

Evaluation

  • Age ≤4 months: hip ultrasonography
  • Age >4 months: hip x-rays

This patient's presentation is concerning for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), an abnormal development of the femoral head and acetabulum.  Risk factors include breech presentation, female sex, and family history of DDH.  Because many patients have no risk factors, all infants should have serial hip examinations to assess for the following findings associated with DDH:

  • Leg asymmetry:  Apparent femoral shortening (ie, due to posterior displacement) is assessed via the Galeazzi test, in which the height of the knees is compared when the patient is supine with flexed knees, or via the presence of asymmetric skinfolds on the groin, buttock, or thigh.  Both assessments are positive in this child, raising concern for DDH.

  • Hip instability:  Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers are used to assess joint stability, and a palpable clunk may indicate a dislocated hip that can be reduced.  Although hip instability is highly specific for DDH, sensitivity is variable (eg, examiner dependent) and negative/equivocal findings do not exclude the diagnosis, as in this patient.

Infants with an abnormal examination should undergo bilateral hip imaging.  Infants age ≤4 months should undergo hip ultrasonography because the acetabulum and femoral head are cartilaginous, limiting the utility of x-rays; ultrasonography also allows for dynamic assessment of hip anatomy and stability.  Positive findings include a shallow acetabulum with a dislocated femoral head.  After age 4 months, when the femoral head and acetabulum are ossified, x-rays are preferred (Choice F).

DDH in infancy is treated with a Pavlik harness, a splint that holds the hip in flexion and abduction.  Early treatment (typically before age 6 months) portends a favorable prognosis.

(Choices A and E)  Lumbosacral ultrasonography is indicated for neonates with cutaneous lumbosacral findings (eg, sacral dimple, hair tuft), potential indications of a neural tube defect; abnormal findings are followed by MRI to assess the extent of the defect.  This patient has no lumbosacral findings and does not warrant spinal imaging.

(Choices B and C)  Repeat examination can be considered for neonates age <1 month with isolated, mild hip instability, which often resolves spontaneously.  In contrast, reassurance or repeat examination is inappropriate in a child age 2 months with multiple signs of DDH (ie, asymmetric thigh folds, positive Galeazzi test).

Educational objective:
Suspected developmental dysplasia of the hip (eg, hip instability, leg asymmetry) in infants age ≤4 months should be evaluated with hip ultrasonography; x-ray is performed in older patients.

questionList.title: Developmental hip dysplasia

questionList.questionText: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for evaluation of leg pain.  The patient first noticed a dull ache in her left thigh a month ago.  The pain is intermittent, worse after skipping rope with friends, and typically resolves after rest or ibuprofen.  She does not recall any inciting injury to the leg.  Prior to last month, the patient had never experienced any similar pain.  Medical history is unremarkable.  She takes no medications.  Family history is notable for sickle cell disease.  Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F).  BMI is at the 97th percentile for age.  The abdomen is soft with no hepatosplenomegaly.  A few soft, nontender, mobile, 1-cm inguinal lymph nodes are palpable bilaterally.  Skin examination reveals a few small, healing abrasions over the bilateral anterior knees.  The left hip demonstrates decreased range of motion with internal rotation.  There is no increased warmth over the joint.  The left foot points laterally during ambulation.  Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Slipped capital femoral epiphysis

Risk factors

  • Obesity
  • Adolescence

Clinical

presentation

  • Dull hip pain
  • Referred knee pain
  • Altered gait
  • Limited internal rotation of hip

Diagnosis

  • Posteriorly displaced femoral head on x-ray

Treatment

  • Non–weight bearing
  • Surgical pinning

Complications 

  • Avascular necrosis
  • Osteoarthritis

This obese (BMI >95th percentile) patient with dull thigh pain and decreased range of motion of the hip likely has slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).  SCFE occurs when excessive shearing at the proximal femoral physis (growth plate) weakens the growth plate, causing anterosuperior displacement of the proximal femur diaphysis and giving the appearance of a posteriorly displaced femoral head.  Obese adolescents are at highest risk due to increased mechanical strain on the hip.

Symptoms most commonly include chronic (>3 weeks), intermittent, dull pain/ache of the hip, thigh, or knee that is exacerbated by activity, as seen in this patient.  The leg is typically externally rotated (foot pointed laterally), and gait may be altered due to pain.  On examination, decreased range of motion (particularly internal rotation) and tenderness of the hip may be present.  Abduction and external rotation of the thigh during passive flexion of the hip is characteristic.  Diagnosis is confirmed by visualization of a posteriorly slipped femoral head on x-ray.

(Choice A)  Septic arthritis, a bacterial joint infection, presents with acute fever, joint pain, inability to bear weight, and a swollen, warm joint.  In contrast, this patient is afebrile with chronic symptoms and no joint swelling.

(Choice B)  Expansion of malignant cells in the bone marrow is characteristic of leukemia, which can present with chronic bone pain.  Systemic findings such as fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly are typical.  This patient is otherwise asymptomatic, and her soft, nontender, 1-cm inguinal lymph nodes are normal, physiologic nodes.

(Choice D)  Transient synovitis is characterized by self-limiting, intraarticular inflammation and presents in children age 3-8 with acute hip pain and limp following a viral illness.  This patient's age and chronic symptoms make SCFE more likely.

(Choice E)  Vasoocclusive crisis due to red cell sickling causes bone pain in patients with sickle cell disease.  Undiagnosed sickle cell disease is unlikely in this adolescent because pain crises typically present in early childhood.

Educational objective:
Slipped capital femoral epiphysis occurs when excessive shearing at the proximal femoral physis weakens the growth plate, causing displacement of the proximal femur diaphysis.  Patients are classically obese adolescents with chronic, dull pain along the thigh or knee that worsens with activity.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis

answerChoiceList.choice: Bacterial infection of the joint space
Expansion of malignant cells in bone marrow
Shearing at the proximal femoral physis
Vasoocclusion from intravascular red cell sickling

questionList.questionText: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for leg pain.  Over the past 3 months, the patient has had bilateral leg pain that occurs only at night.  The pain is primarily in the thighs, although it occasionally occurs in the shins as well.  Each episode lasts a few hours and improves with massage or over-the-counter analgesics.  The pain has not worsened since it began, and he has no leg pain during the day.  The patient can walk, run, and play at school without complaint, although the pain does more commonly occur on days when he runs a lot.  He has no fever, chills, or weight loss, and there is no history of recent trauma.  On examination, the patient has full range of motion of the hips and knees bilaterally.  No swelling or tenderness to palpation is noted, and he has a normal gait.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Growing pains (idiopathic nocturnal pains of childhood)

Epidemiology

  • Children age 3-12

Clinical features

  • Episodic, bilateral lower extremity (eg, thighs, calves) pain
    • Occurs primarily at night
    • More likely to occur after increased physical exertion
  • No systemic symptoms, joint involvement, or activity limitations
  • Normal physical examination

Diagnosis & treatment

  • Clinical diagnosis based on characteristic history* & examination
  • Parental education & reassurance
  • Massage, heat, analgesics, or stretching exercises

Course

  • May wax/wane for months to years
  • Self-resolves by adolescence

*Unilateral pain can occur in growing pains but warrants evaluation (eg, x-ray) to exclude alternate diagnoses (eg, osteoid osteoma, osteosarcoma).

This patient with recurrent, nocturnal bilateral leg pain likely has growing pains, also called idiopathic nocturnal pains of childhood.  Growing pains are benign and the most common cause of musculoskeletal pain in children age 3-12.  The etiology is unknown, but, contrary to the name, the onset and location of the pain seem unrelated to growth.

Growing pains are characterized by nonprogressive bilateral leg pain that usually involves the thighs, calves, or shins.  The pain occurs in the evenings or at night, lasts minutes to hours, and is episodic (often with pain-free days or weeks).  Patients can perform daily activities without limitation, and physical examination is normal.  Growing pains are a clinical diagnosis; pathologic causes should be considered for systemic symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss), abnormal examination findings (eg, joint inflammation, limp), or progressive or unilateral pain.

Management includes reassurance and supportive care, including massage, heat, analgesics, or stretching exercises.  Although episodes may occur more frequently after increased daytime physical exertion, as in this patient, limitation of activity or bracing is not recommended (Choice E).  Growing pains self-resolve but may recur for months to years.

(Choice B)  A bone scan may be performed in patients with leg pain due to a suspected localized inflammatory process (eg, osteomyelitis).  In contrast to growing pains in this patient, these conditions typically cause persistent, unilateral pain and systemic symptoms.

(Choice C)  Leukemia can cause bilateral long bone pain, and a complete blood count often demonstrates multiple cytopenias.  However, the affected area is usually tender to palpation due to bone marrow expansion from leukemic cell infiltration, and most patients have systemic symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss) and other abnormal examination findings (eg, petechiae, splenomegaly).

(Choice D)  Bone tumors (eg, osteoid osteoma, osteosarcoma) are usually diagnosed with x-ray in patients with recurrent or persistent leg pain; osteoid osteoma often causes nocturnal pain responsive to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications.  However, in both benign and malignant lesions, the pain is unilateral and often associated with progressive pain and a palpable mass.

Educational objective:
Growing pains are episodic bilateral leg pains that occur at night in children with no associated systemic symptoms, activity limitations, or abnormal examination findings.  The diagnosis is clinical, and management includes parental reassurance and supportive care (eg, massage, heat, analgesics, stretching exercises).

questionList.title: Growing pains

newExamYearQuestionList.questionText: A 24-year-old woman comes in with several months of low back and buttock pain.  Her pain is most severe early in the morning and fades as the day progresses.  There is no recent history of significant illness or trauma.  On examination, tenderness is present in the lower lumbar spine.  Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal and equal in all extremities.  Hip x-ray shows widening of the sacroiliac joint space, as seen in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
newExamYearQuestionList.explanationText:
Treatment of ankylosing spondylitis

Nonpharmacologic
measures

  • Exercise (postural exercises, ROM/stretching exercises)
  • Physical therapy

Initial treatment

  • NSAIDs (eg, ibuprofen, naproxen)
  • COX-2 inhibitors (eg, celecoxib)

Treatment failure/
disease progression

  • TNF-α inhibitors (eg, etanercept, infliximab)
  • Anti–IL-17 antibodies (eg, secukinumab)

COX-2 = cyclooxygenase-2; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; ROM = range of motion; TNF-α = tumor necrosis factor-alpha.

This patient has inflammatory back pain (ie, onset age <40, chronic/insidious onset, worse with rest/better with activity) and spinal tenderness.  Her pelvic x-rays shows early findings of sacroiliitis, including widening of the sacroiliac joint space (due to bone erosions) and sclerosis of the subchondral bone.  This is a characteristic presentation of ankylosing spondylitis (AS).  As joint disease progresses, narrowing and eventual fusion of the sacroiliac joint is classically seen on pelvic radiography.

In AS, prostaglandins have a synergistic effect with the inflammatory cytokines (eg, tumor necrosis factor-alpha [TNF-alpha], IL-17) in promoting syndesmophyte formation and ankylosis.  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (eg, ibuprofen, naproxen) and cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors (eg, celecoxib) reduce the formation of prostaglandins.  These agents often provide substantial relief of symptoms in AS and inhibit progression of the disease.  In many patients (70%-80%), NSAIDs are the only agents needed to reduce pain and stiffness.  NSAIDs also help the peripheral arthritis often seen in association with AS.

(Choice A)  Colchicine is a microtubule inhibitor commonly used in the treatment of gout but is not recommended for AS.

(Choice C)  Options for pain relief in patients who have persistent symptoms on NSAID therapy include acetaminophen and tramadol.  Opioids (eg, oxycodone) are not well studied for AS and, unlike NSAIDs, do not address the underlying inflammatory process.

(Choice D)  Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections can be used in select patients with AS for treatment of sacroiliitis, peripheral arthritis, or enthesitis (inflammation at tendon insertions).  Systemic glucocorticoids (eg, prednisone) are generally not effective.

(Choice E)  Anti-TNF (eg, etanercept, infliximab) and anti–IL-17 (eg, secukinumab) agents are effective for patients who have progressive disease despite NSAIDs.  However, these medications have significant toxicity and are not used as first-line treatment because many patients do well with NSAIDs alone.

Educational objective:
First-line treatment options for ankylosing spondylitis include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors, which provide substantial relief of symptoms and may inhibit progression of the disease for long periods.
